dict.string: the minimal unit of meaning
the smallest meaningful chunks in language
words are made up of morphemes:
we can't point to any pard of "dog" or "Toronto" and assign it meaning
but "dogs" has dog and the plural marker -s
morphemes cannot be divided into smaller meaningful units:
a word and a morpheme are similar but not the same.
morphology is the study of the structure and formation of words
some words have one morpheme, some have many.
every word has a root morpheme, on which the meaning of a word is based.
nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, prepositions, pronouns, conjunctions, determiners, complementizers…
quick review of grammatical categories (aka parts of speech)
e.g. cat, walk, tall
free morphemes: any unit of meaning that can stand by itself in a language.
e.g. -s plural morpheme in "cats", -ed past tense morpheme in "walked", -est superlative morpheme in "tallest"
bound morpheme/affix: any unit of meaning that cannot stand by itself.
FACT: every word of every language is composed of at least a single morpheme.
A. {walk, walks, walking, walked}
B. {runner, jumper, swimmer}
1. select related forms for comparison.
set A has walk as the common unit and it's associated with human powered travel by foot
set B has er as the common unit and it's attaches to verbs to form nouns that refer to people who do the action of the verb.
2. identify similar parts and their meanings
A. {walk, walk-s, walk-ing, walk-ed}
B. {run-er, jumper, swim-er}
3. divide the forms into parts, according to their morpheme boundries
4. we end up with: walk-er
take "walker" as an example
How many morphemes are there in a word?
change the meaning of the root, called derivational morphemes
among the functional morphemes are morphemes that:
indicate purely functional/grammatical information, called inflectional morphemes.
can add new lexical morphemes to a language
nouns, verbs, adj. and adv. are lexical and open.
the set of lexical morphemes is an open class.
some morphemes are highly meaningful, they refer to objects, actions, attributes, ideas, etc.
languages rally add new functional items
conjunctions (and, or, but), pronouns and prepositions are functional and closed.
the set of functional morphemes is a closed class.
other morphemes serve grammatical purposes; harder to define.
types of morphemes
prefixes: attach at beginning of other forms
suffixes: attach at end of other forms
infixes: morphemes that are inserted inside or root morpheme are called.
circumfixes: two-part morphemes that appear on both side of a root morpheme.
other languages make productive use of infixes and circumfixes
about Bound Affixes
linguistic diversity: forming words using affixes is called concatenate morphology because we link together different morphemes into a chain.
for verbs, they can indicate information about time (tense), possibility (mood), and internal structure of an event (aspect).

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1265 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaGrande;\f1\fnil\fcharset0 LucidaGrande-Bold;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red0\green0\blue0;} \pard\tx560\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\pardirnatural
\f0\fs24 \cf2 for verbs, they can indicate information about \f1\b time \f0\b0 (tense), \f1\b possibility \f0\b0 (mood), and \f1\b internal structure of an event \f0\b0 (aspect).}
for nouns, they can indicate whether or not a noun is singular or plural and masculine or feminine, or the grammatical person.
for adj., they can indicate the degree to which the adj holds.
inflectional morphemes provide grammatical information about the word they attach to:
inflectional morphology and word order are the best clues as the grammatical category of a word.
More on inflectional morphemes
most lexical morphemes in English are free morphemes, some are bound: *cran, cranberry, *twi, twilight
call them bound roots
several languages have many more bound roots than English
these morphemes are relatively meaningful but cannot stand alone.
Words and Morphemes
derivational morphology is the most productive. that is, we can add derivational affixes to any new word and create even more words.
many derivation suffixes in English can be used to change the grammatical category of a word (i.e., noun, verb, adjective) or augment its meaning in someway.
in English, few if any derivational prefixes change the grammatical category or their roots like many suffixes do. Rather, they tend to change the meaning of the root in someway.
prefixes can attach to verbs/n/adj to create new verbs/n/adj
prefixes are less productive than suffixes in English, and there's often disagreement about what prefix (with similar meaning) to use for new words.
another way to create new words is to combine two roots. bitter-sweet, rain-bow, dog-food, ice-cream

most English compounds are right-headed: if the first element (on the left) is grammatical category X and the second element is grammatical category Y, the grammatical category of the compound will be Y.
acronyms are made by combining the first letter of several words: SCUBA = Self Contained Underwater Breathing Apparatus; LASER = Light Amplification (by) Stimulated Emission (of) Radiation
Initialisms are acronyms in which each letter is pronounced separately: UTM, RCMP = Royal Canadian Mounted Police
acronyms and initialisms
involves shortening words to create new ones.
when parts of two (or more) words are combined, the resulting form is called a blend, e.g. smog, medicare, Frankenstorm

the word peddler was historically a single morpheme. however, b/c it ends with er, which looks like the suffix -er that attaches to verbs to create a noun meaning "a person who does X", speakers reanalyzed it as being a combination of peddle and -er. The verb peddle was born.
other e.g.: edit (from editor), burgle (from burglar), pea ( from pease with the old plural peasen)
occurs when speakers reanalyze a word
The Earl of Sandwich -> sandwich
Heinrich Hertz -> Hertz (Hz.)
Don Quixote -> quixotic
Franz Kafka -> Kafkaesque
are words derived from names
languages employ various ways of making new words.
analytic languages are also called isolating languages because almost every morpheme is a free morpheme (i.e., one morpheme = one word).
synthetic-agglutinative languages combine several morphemes to form a single, multi morphemic word with clear morpheme boundaries.
synthetic-fusional languages combine several morphemes to form a single, multi morphemic word but the individual bits of meaning can't be easily identified.
polysynthetic languages combine several morphemes to form a single, multi morphemic word that is a complete sentence!
types of morphology
Morphology in Other Languages
different forms/variants of a single morpheme are called allomorphs.
'a' is used before consonants; 'an' is used before vowels
Allomorphy: The English Indefinite Article
Allomorphy: The English Past Tense
Allomorphy: The English Plural
Intro to morphology
some affixes can only attach to specific types of words (nouns, verbs etc)
different hierarchical structures can lead to differences in meanings.
why? b/c
complex words have an internal structure that is hierarchical.
therefore un- must attach to the root happy before the -ness suffix changes the word’s grammatical category to a noun.
the un- prefix can't attach to nouns (uncoffee?, unpencil?, etc)
the best evidence for this hierarchical ordering comes from words with both prefixes and suffixes.
"an unlockable lock"?
Structural ambiguity: the hierarchical structure of words sometimes leads to structural ambiguity
